chargeHist.descr: Tampering w/ a Global Positioning System Tracking Device
Tampering w/ a Global Positioning System Tracking Device

result.execSummary:
All charges against Erik McDonald in this case have been dismissed. These charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Erik McDonald is presumed innocent.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

judgments.dispoDesc:
*dismissed without prejudice.
*As a review of Department of Corrections records confirms that the GPS device assigned to the defendant was not assigned pursuant to either section 301.48 or 301.49 Wis. Stats. Accordingly, this section of the criminal code does not apply to the defendant's alleged act of
cutting off his GPS ankle bracelet. Therefore, the State moves to dismiss. The State will be issuing a new, misdemeanor complaint charging the defendant with criminal damage to property as a repeat offender.

charges.descr: Tampering w/ a Global Positioning System Tracking Device

Order of Dismissal /s/ PB 10/12/22 
*dismissed without prejudice.
*As a review of Department of Corrections records confirms that the GPS device assigned to the defendant was not assigned pursuant to either section 301.48 or 301.49 Wis. Stats. Accordingly, this section of the criminal code does not apply to the defendant's alleged act of cutting off his GPS ankle bracelet. Therefore, the State moves to dismiss. The State will be issuing a new, misdemeanor complaint charging the defendant with criminal damage to property as a repeat offender.
